H0.text: Intensity of light is the stimulus that causes a responding plant to demonstrate phototropism.

H1.text: Direction of light is the stimulus that causes a responding plant to demonstrate phototropism.

H2.text: Length of day is the stimulus that causes a responding plant to demonstrate phototropism.

H3.text: Time of day is the stimulus that causes a responding plant to demonstrate phototropism.

A4.text: The amounts of PHOT1 and PHOT2 present are different depending on the age of the plant and the intensity of the light.

A5.text: In the presence of asymmetric light, auxin will move towards the shaded side and promote elongation of the cells on that side to cause the plant to curve towards the light source.

A6.text: Phototropins are blue light photoreceptor proteins

A7.text: Phototropins specifically will cause stems to bend towards light and stomata to open

A8.text: Plant growth is also affected by the colour spectrum of light, a process known as photomorphogenesis.
